verses.text: Bless the LORD, O my soul. O LORD my God, you are very great! You are clothed with splendor and majesty,
verses.comment: The psalm begins with a personal call to worship, recognizing God's greatness and majesty. The clothing imagery hints at God's transcendent glory above all creation.

verses.text: covering yourself with light as with a garment, stretching out the heavens like a curtain.
verses.comment: God's radiance and creative power are depicted—with all creation as his handiwork. The 'light' imagery connects to Genesis 1:3, and points to the Divine as the true source of all things.

verses.text: He lays the beams of his upper rooms in the waters; he makes the clouds his chariot; he walks on the wings of the wind;
verses.comment: God's sovereignty over creation includes the skies and weather. These poetic images recall God as the sustainer and ruler of all natural forces.

verses.text: He makes his messengers winds, his servants a flame of fire.
verses.comment: Frequently cited in Hebrews 1:7 to highlight the distinction between God and angels. The New Testament applies this text to show the subservience of angels to Christ (Heb. 1:7).

verses.text: He set the earth on its foundations, so that it should never be moved forever.
verses.comment: God's act of creation establishes stability. The permanence of the earth links to His sustaining power; this has both literal and spiritual implications in later tradition, including New Creation imagery.

verses.text: You covered it with the deep as with a garment; the waters stood above the mountains.
verses.comment: A reference to the creation account and the Flood, symbolizing both judgment and the potential for rebirth. The covering with waters echoes the themes of chaos subdued by God.

verses.text: At your rebuke they fled; at the sound of your thunder they hurried away.
verses.comment: God's word commands the natural world. The parallels with Exodus and the Flood show God's ultimate authority, and spiritually, the separation from chaos towards order.

verses.text: The mountains rose, the valleys sank down to the place that you appointed for them.
verses.comment: The established order of creation is by God's hand, reinforcing His ongoing providence.

verses.text: You set a boundary that they may not cross, so that they might not cover the earth again.
verses.comment: Divine order and restraint: after the flood, the waters are held back, symbolizing God’s covenantal faithfulness. This points forward to later covenant theology.

verses.text: He sends springs into the valleys; they flow between the hills;
verses.comment: God provides life-giving water, a sign of His ongoing care for all creation.

verses.text: They give drink to every beast of the field; the wild donkeys quench their thirst.
verses.comment: Everything, from the smallest animal to mankind, depends on God’s provision.

verses.text: Beside them the birds of the heavens dwell; they sing among the branches.
verses.comment: Creation itself is pictured as joyfully praising God. This resonates with the idea of creation being good (Gen. 1:31).

verses.text: He waters the mountains from his upper rooms; the earth is satisfied with the fruit of your works.
verses.comment: God’s care is comprehensive, satisfying the earth and all in it. There is a sense of spiritual fulfillment, prefiguring God's satisfaction of human spiritual needs.

verses.text: He makes grass grow for the cattle, and plants for man to cultivate, that he may bring forth food from the earth,
verses.comment: The divine order includes mankind’s stewardship of creation. This reinforces man's role as a co-worker with God, a theme developed in spiritual traditions focused on the dignity of human work.

verses.text: and wine that gladdens the heart of man, oil to make his face shine, and bread that strengthens man's heart.
verses.comment: The three-fold gifts—wine, oil, and bread—have a sacramental quality, symbolizing joy, anointing, and sustenance. These will later be echoed in New Testament imagery, especially in the Lord’s Supper.

verses.text: The trees of the LORD are satisfied, the cedars of Lebanon that he planted.
verses.comment: Even the grandest trees depend on God. The cedars of Lebanon recall images of the Temple and spiritual flourishing.

verses.text: Where the birds make their nests; the stork has her home in the fir trees.
verses.comment: God provides for all creatures’ needs, showing his providence for every living thing.

verses.text: The high mountains are for the wild goats; the rocks are a refuge for the badgers.
verses.comment: Every animal has its place by God's design—testifying to both order and care.

verses.text: He made the moon to mark the seasons; the sun knows its setting.
verses.comment: God’s created order includes not only the earth but the heavenly bodies whose precise purposes point to an intelligent design.

verses.text: You make darkness, and it is night, when all the beasts of the forest creep out.
verses.comment: The rhythms of day and night show the wisdom of the Creator. In spiritual tradition, darkness and light also represent spiritual states.

verses.text: The young lions roar for their prey, seeking their food from God.
verses.comment: Even fierce creatures depend on God. All living things are his dependents, whether realized or not.

verses.text: When the sun rises, they steal away and lie down in their dens.
verses.comment: The cycle of day and night is part of God's good order. All life submits to His rhythms.

verses.text: Man goes out to his work, and to his labor until evening.
verses.comment: Work is part of human vocation after the fall, but the psalm recasts it as part of the ordered goodness of creation.

verses.text: O LORD, how many are your works! In wisdom you have made them all; the earth is full of your creatures.
verses.comment: God’s wisdom is the foundation of creation. This wisdom is interpreted in later tradition as personified Logos (John 1:1–3).

verses.text: Here is the sea, great and wide, which swarms with countless creatures, living things both small and great.
verses.comment: The teeming life of the sea is another testimony to God’s power and abundance.

verses.text: There go the ships, and Leviathan, which you formed to play in it.
verses.comment: Leviathan, the great sea creature, is under God’s sovereignty. Victory over chaos monsters prefigures spiritual battles later fulfilled by Christ’s victory.

verses.text: These all look to you, to give them their food in due season.
verses.comment: God’s daily provision sustains all life and prefigures dependence upon God’s grace.

verses.text: When you give it to them, they gather it up; when you open your hand, they are filled with good things.
verses.comment: The imagery of God's open hand is a symbol of divine generosity, a motif seen throughout Scripture and fully revealed in the Incarnation.

verses.text: When you hide your face, they are dismayed; when you take away their breath, they die and return to their dust.
verses.comment: Human and animal life is dependent on the presence and spirit of God. This reflects on the frailty of life and the need for ongoing communion with God.

verses.text: When you send out your Spirit, they are created, and you renew the face of the ground.
verses.comment: Here the Spirit (Ruach) is God’s creative force, prefiguring New Testament associations of the Holy Spirit as giver of new life (cf. John 20:22, Acts 2:4).

verses.text: May the glory of the LORD endure forever; may the LORD rejoice in his works;
verses.comment: God’s glory is bound up with creation. In tradition, this points to creation as sustained by God’s will and joy.

verses.text: who looks on the earth and it trembles, who touches the mountains and they smoke.
verses.comment: God’s presence is powerful and awe-inspiring. The imagery recalls the Sinai theophany, a reminder of God’s holiness and transcendence.

verses.text: I will sing to the LORD as long as I live; I will sing praise to my God while I have being.
verses.comment: The response to God’s majestic works is lifelong praise; a key theme in both personal and corporate worship.

verses.text: May my meditation be pleasing to him, for I rejoice in the LORD.
verses.comment: There is an emphasis on the acceptability of worship and meditation before God—an idea closely linked to the value of interior devotion and silent prayer.

verses.text: Let sinners be consumed from the earth, and let the wicked be no more! Bless the LORD, O my soul! Praise the LORD!
verses.comment: The psalm ends with a longing for the triumph of God's righteousness, but also a renewed call to praise. As with other psalms, spiritual tradition sees here both a prayer for the defeat of evil and a yearning for the fullness of redemption and sanctification.
